Central Banking (Inflation Targeting Reg.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.5 months (resolves with INDEC's December 2025 YoY inflation report, typically published mid-January 2026).
Central Banking (Inflation Targeting Reg.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Central Banking and inflation targeting regimes, my perspective is highly relevant because Argentina’s current monetary environment, post-Milei reforms, is a textbook case of attempted disinflation in a chronic high-inflation, low-credibility regime. My knowledge of how persistent inflation responds to fiscal-monetary adjustments, expectations management, and institutional bottlenecks helps assess the credibility and sustainability of recent disinflation, as well as the risks of reversal.
Central Banking (Inflation Targeting Reg.status_quo: YoY inflation is trending down rapidly, last officially reported at 31.8% (September 2025), with monthly inflation hovering around 2%. The status quo is continued disinflation, but just barely above the 30% threshold. If nothing changed, inflation would likely be near but slightly above 30% for December 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Disinflation momentum and monetary policy stance
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. While rapid disinflation has occurred due to sharp fiscal and monetary contraction, the last mile is the hardest: getting from 30% to below 30%, especially in a fragile institutional context, is historically difficult. Sticky inflation expectations and wage/price indexation are typical in Argentina, and the recent uptick to 2.1% monthly inflation in September 2025 shows this resistance.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Credibility of statistics and policy sustainability
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. There is significant skepticism about the accuracy of official statistics (see claims of manipulated poverty and inflation data), as well as doubts about the sustainability of the current policies given their social and political costs. If data is massaged or policies are reversed post-election, sub-30% inflation becomes less likely.

Decreases probability. The October 26, 2025, midterms are a major risk. If Milei’s coalition loses, foreign support (like the US/IMF 'blindaje') may evaporate, and Peronists may block or reverse key reforms. Markets have already shown volatility in anticipation of this, with brief surges in inflation expectations and peso depreciation after Peronist wins. Political instability can easily trigger a return to higher inflation, especially given Argentina’s low policy credibility.

Increases probability. The $20B swap and IMF support, combined with a temporary stabilization of the peso, have helped keep inflation on a declining path. Continued access to external finance could allow the central bank to smooth shocks and keep disinflation on track, at least through the end of 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base rate/historical experience of Argentina and comparable regimes
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. In Argentina, when inflation has been above 30% YoY, it is extremely rare to see it fall below that threshold in less than two years absent full stabilization (e.g., convertibility in 1991). The last mile of disinflation is typically the hardest due to entrenched expectations, backward-looking contracts, and price inertia. IMF projections and private forecasts remain above 30% for 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent inflation data and near-term trend
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. The official YoY rate has fallen from nearly 300% to just above 30% in under a year, and monthly inflation has stabilized below 2%. If this trend continues, sub-30% YoY in December is mathematically possible.

Central Banking (Inflation Targeting Reg.no_scenario: After the midterms, Milei’s political position is weakened; foreign support is reduced or conditional. Social unrest or opposition pressure forces partial reversal of austerity, monetary/fiscal discipline loosens, and the peso weakens. Monthly inflation, already ticking up (2.1% in September), stays above 2% in Q4 2025 or even accelerates. YoY inflation bottoms out around 31–33% in December 2025, failing to cross the 30% threshold.
Central Banking (Inflation Targeting Reg.yes_scenario: Milei’s coalition retains enough power after the midterms to sustain fiscal/monetary discipline and receives continued external support. Monthly inflation remains at or below 2% for the final quarter of 2025, or even drifts down to 1.5%. With the YoY base dropping sharply (removing high-inflation months from late 2024), the December 2025 YoY CPI prints at 29.5% or lower. Official statistics align with the government’s claims, and no major peso devaluation or policy reversal occurs.
Central Banking (Inflation Targeting Reg.final_reasoning: While the disinflation since late 2023 is breathtaking, the final step—crossing from just above 30% to below it—is the hardest, especially in an institutionally fragile, low-credibility regime like Argentina. The recent uptick in monthly CPI (2.1% in September), persistent wage/price inertia, skepticism over official data, and mounting political risks (midterm elections, risk of policy reversal) all suggest that sustaining or further reducing inflation may prove very challenging. IMF and market-based forecasts remain above 30% for December 2025, and base rates for such rapid disinflation are low. However, the mathematical trend does leave room for a sub-30% print, especially if discipline is maintained and no external shock hits. Given all this, the probability of YoY inflation being below 30% in December 2025 is higher than it would have been a few months ago, but remains modest—significantly less than 50%, but not close to zero.

Central Banking (Monetary Policy Transmi.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.5 months (until Dec 2025 inflation data is released in Jan 2026)
Central Banking (Monetary Policy Transmi.perspective_relevance: As an expert in central banking and monetary policy transmission, my perspective is highly relevant because Argentina's inflation path depends critically on the effectiveness and credibility of the central bank's monetary policy, the transmission of monetary and fiscal tightening through the economy, the persistence of inflation expectations, and the structural weaknesses of the Argentine monetary system. Understanding the lagged effects of policy actions, the risks of peso devaluation, and the potential for policy or political reversals is central to forecasting year-over-year inflation outcomes.
Central Banking (Monetary Policy Transmi.status_quo: As of September 2025, Argentina's official YoY inflation was 31.8%, with monthly inflation between 1.9% and 2.1%. Official and many private projections for end-2025 inflation are near or just above 30%, with a strong downward trend from the triple digits of 2023 and early 2024.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. While monetary tightening has sharply reduced monthly inflation, transmission lags mean that some inflationary inertia persists. Argentina's history shows that even after aggressive tightening, inflation can remain sticky above targets for longer than models predict.

Decreases probability. The peso remains vulnerable to sudden devaluation, especially if political risks or external shocks materialize. A sudden depreciation would immediately transmit into higher consumer prices, potentially pushing YoY inflation above 30%.

Mixed/slightly increases probability. Milei's deep spending cuts have helped reduce inflation, but austerity is politically fragile. Social unrest or a political reversal (e.g., a Peronist resurgence after midterms) could trigger fiscal or monetary loosening, but with just 2 months left to the target, the clock is running out for any reversal to meaningfully impact Dec 2025 YoY figures.

Decreases probability. Argentina has almost never achieved sub-30% YoY inflation after a hyperinflationary episode within two years, barring brief windows in the early 1990s convertibility plan. The base rate for sub-30% inflation after a triple-digit episode is very low.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Official Data Reliability and Shadow Inflation
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. There is credible reporting that official inflation and poverty figures may understate actual price pressures, especially for essentials and services. If political incentives intensify to massage the data near year-end, the official figure may be held just under 30%, but skepticism remains.

Increases probability. The collapse in monthly inflation to near 2% (and some months below) is a powerful disinflationary sign, and YoY figures are declining by several percentage points each month. If this pace holds, December's YoY figure could plausibly come in just under 30%.
Increases probability. US and IMF support have shored up reserves and allowed the central bank to defend the peso, reducing the risk of an immediate currency crisis before year-end.

Central Banking (Monetary Policy Transmi.no_scenario: Despite monthly inflation holding near 2%, the YoY figure for December 2025 comes in at 30% or slightly above, due to statistical carryover from higher 2024 inflation, a minor currency slip, or because critical prices (utilities, transportation, food) spike due to new subsidy cuts or exogenous shocks. Alternatively, official data is not sufficiently manipulated downward, or a last-minute political reversal or unrest triggers market instability.
Central Banking (Monetary Policy Transmi.yes_scenario: Monthly inflation remains below 2% for October-December, and the base effect from high late-2024 inflation drops out, pulling the YoY figure below 30%. The government avoids a major currency or political crisis before year-end, and official INDEC data reports a compliant figure, possibly with some data smoothing.
Central Banking (Monetary Policy Transmi.final_reasoning: The odds are extremely close, with the most recent data showing the YoY rate at 31.8% in September and monthly inflation at 2.1%. If monthly inflation stays at or below 2%, and given the sharp drop from triple digits over the year, it's mathematically possible for YoY inflation to fall just under 30% by December. However, the margin is razor thin, and risks remain on both the upside (currency, political, or data reliability shocks) and downside (continued disinflation momentum, political incentives to present a 'victory' for Milei). As a central banking expert, I put extra weight on historical stickiness and the possibility of a late-year currency event, but also recognize the power of the current trend and the short time window for a reversal. The most likely outcome is a December 2025 YoY inflation figure between 28% and 32%, with a slight edge to it coming in just below 30%—especially given the government's incentive to deliver a symbolic win and the technical feasibility if current trends hold. Therefore, I assign a probability of 58%.

Sovereign Risk Analysis (Country Risk As.time_to_resolution: About 2.5 months (until December 2025 inflation data is published, likely mid-January 2026)
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Country Risk As.perspective_relevance: As a sovereign risk analyst, I focus on macroeconomic fundamentals, policy credibility, political stability, market expectations, and the relationship between external support and domestic reform credibility. My expertise is particularly relevant for assessing the durability of disinflationary trends in unstable political economies like Argentina, where historical base rates of persistent high inflation and policy reversals are high.
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Country Risk As.status_quo: Annual inflation as of September 2025 is reported at about 31.8% (INDEC), with recent monthly inflation readings between 1.5% and 2.1%. The trend since Milei's inauguration has been sharply downward, from nearly 300% to low 30s. IMF and market expectations for year-end 2025 range from 28% to over 41%, with substantial uncertainty. The status quo, if nothing changed, is a continued gradual decline in inflation, likely finishing the year around the current level (31-33%).

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability—Inflation is falling sharply, with several months of monthly inflation below 2%, suggesting YoY readings could soon dip below 30%.

Increases probability—Milei's reforms are holding for now, but the October 2025 midterms and Peronist resurgence threaten policy continuity. If reforms are reversed or watered down, inflation could re-accelerate, making sub-30% less likely.
Increases probability—Argentina’s historical tendency is to relapse into high inflation even after short-term stabilization, due to lack of deep structural reforms and political consensus.
Increases uncertainty—There are credible allegations that INDEC’s headline inflation may understate real household inflation, but for resolution purposes, official numbers are what matter.

Decreases probability—Temporary US and IMF support has stabilized the peso and bought time, but these are stopgaps. A sudden withdrawal or loss of confidence could renew pressure on the currency and inflation.

Increases probability—Most reputable forecasts (IMF, REM, others) cluster between 28% and 41% for end-2025. While some private/official projections are sub-30%, the balance of expert opinion is just above the threshold.
Increases probability—Pre-election spending or post-election instability could create inflationary pressures, especially if Milei loses legislative support or is forced to compromise reforms.

Sovereign Risk Analysis (Country Risk As.no_scenario: Milei’s government maintains or tightens fiscal and monetary policy, monthly inflation remains at or below 2%, and exchange rate volatility is subdued. The YoY inflation rate continues to decline but only reaches ~30-32% in December 2025 due to base effects from late 2024’s high readings. Alternatively, a modest post-election fiscal loosening or market nerves cause a slight uptick, keeping inflation just above 30%.
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Country Risk As.yes_scenario: Policy discipline holds, and/or the disinflation process accelerates (e.g., monthly inflation drops to 1% or less in Q4 2025). Support from the US/IMF and/or market confidence persists, with no major shocks or policy reversals. As a result, the December 2025 YoY inflation rate dips just below 30% (e.g., 28-29%). Alternatively, INDEC’s methodology or official reporting leads to a slightly understated inflation print that resolves the question as Yes.
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Country Risk As.final_reasoning:
Argentina’s inflation has fallen dramatically, and the current trajectory (mid-30s% annual, low monthly rates) suggests that a sub-30% YoY figure is mathematically plausible by December 2025. However, the margin is narrow: September’s 31.8% YoY is only slightly above the threshold, and recent months show a plateau or slight uptick (2.1% monthly in September). IMF and market forecasts have actually been raised in recent weeks (now 28-41%, with the IMF at 28% in one report and 41% in another; REM expects 30-35%). The most authoritative forecasts (IMF, REM) cluster just above or at the threshold, highlighting substantial uncertainty.

Political risks are elevated: the October midterms could destabilize Milei’s coalition, trigger policy reversals, or provoke market volatility. While US/IMF support has bought time, it is not a structural fix. Argentina’s long-run base rate is for inflation to rebound or stabilize at higher levels after periods of austerity, especially if social or political backlash erodes reform momentum. That said, the current monthly inflation trend is very low; if it persists for three more months, the YoY figure could comfortably dip below 30%. The official nature of the resolution source (INDEC) means that even if real inflation is higher, the reported number is what matters.

Balancing these factors, the probability is close to even odds but slightly favors a No, given the tendency for inflation to get stuck just above politically salient thresholds, the risk of pre/post-election instability, and the base rate of failed disinflation in Argentina. However, the chance of a Yes is not negligible—if current trends hold, a 28-29% print is possible. Thus, I forecast No with moderate confidence, but not extremely so.

Sovereign Risk Analysis (Emerging Market.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.5 months (until INDEC December 2025 CPI is published, likely in mid-January 2026)
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Emerging Market.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Sovereign Risk Analysis (Emerging Market Macro Analysis), I focus on the durability and credibility of macroeconomic stabilization, the sustainability of inflation reductions, the risk of policy reversals, and the impact of political economy on forward-looking economic indicators. I am attuned to both headline trends and structural vulnerabilities, including base rates for disinflation in chronic high-inflation emerging markets and the credibility of official statistics.
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Emerging Market.status_quo: As of October 2025, Argentina's official year-over-year (YoY) inflation rate is reported around 31.8% (September 2025), with monthly inflation rates hovering at or slightly above 2%. The disinflation trend has been rapid and impressive, but official projections and IMF forecasts for 2025 remain above the 30% threshold.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate of Disinflation in High-Inflation EMs
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Historically, countries with entrenched high inflation rarely sustain such a rapid and deep disinflation to sub-30% YoY in under two years without a regime change or persistent external anchor. Risks of inflation inertia, indexation, and policy slippage are high.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Sustainability of Milei’s Austerity and Political Risks
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. While Milei's policies achieved rapid disinflation, they are socially and politically costly. As the October 2025 midterms approach, political backlash, unrest, or a partial policy reversal is plausible, especially if the opposition gains. The sustainability of deep austerity is questionable in a fragile democracy with populist traditions.

Mixed effect. The US and IMF provided $20bn+ in support, temporarily stabilizing the peso. However, this is a stopgap and does not resolve the underlying dollarization pressure or structural external vulnerability. A new currency shock remains possible.

Decreases probability. There is credible skepticism about official INDEC numbers, especially for poverty and inflation, due to methodology changes and political incentives. Real inflation experienced by households may be higher, and the risk exists for an upward statistical adjustment or post-election data shift.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Momentum of Disinflation and Policy Commitment
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. The actual month-on-month (MoM) inflation rates are low (around or just above 2%), and if this pace continues or improves (as argued by Milei and some international observers), the 12-month YoY number could fall below 30% by December 2025, especially given the high base effect from December 2024.

Decreases probability. The latest IMF (October 2025) projects 2025 inflation at 28%-41% (varies by source), suggesting a central estimate at or above the 30% threshold. Government projections are more optimistic but less credible given political incentives.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Potential for External Shocks or Policy Reversal
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Argentina remains vulnerable to commodity price swings, capital flight, or a sudden stop if international support wanes or the political situation destabilizes post-midterms.

Sovereign Risk Analysis (Emerging Market.no_scenario: Despite ongoing fiscal discipline, inflation momentum stalls: MoM rates hover at 2% or slightly higher through Q4 2025, and by December the YoY figure prints at 30% or just above. Political instability after the midterms, a partial rollback of reforms, a weaker peso, or a commodity shock nudges inflation higher. Alternatively, INDEC makes a statistical adjustment upward after the election, keeping the YoY above 30%.
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Emerging Market.yes_scenario: Milei’s government maintains fiscal and monetary discipline, external support holds, and monthly inflation rates remain at or below 2%. The high December 2024 base means YoY inflation drops precipitously, and by December 2025, the official INDEC number comes in at 29.8% or lower. The government resists post-election populist pressures, and no external shock materializes.
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Emerging Market.final_reasoning: Argentina’s rapid disinflation under Milei has surprised most forecasters, with monthly inflation rates currently at historically low levels. However, the IMF and most independent forecasters still project 2025 inflation at or just above 30%, and political, social, and external risks remain acute. The recent uptick in monthly inflation (2.1% in September) and skepticism about official statistics introduce further doubt. The base effect from December 2024 is favorable, but to meet the <30% threshold, monthly inflation must remain at or below 2% for the rest of the year, with no policy or external shocks. Given Argentina’s history of inflation reversals, the fragility of current policy gains, and the high bar for sustaining such a rapid disinflation in the face of political headwinds, I judge it moderately unlikely that the official YoY CPI will be below 30% for December 2025. The probability is higher than it would be for most countries in similar circumstances, due to the ongoing momentum and favorable base effect, but the risks are tilted to the upside.

Macroeconomics (Quantity Theory of Money.time_to_resolution: About 2.5 months (until mid-January 2026, when December 2025 YoY inflation data will be published)
Macroeconomics (Quantity Theory of Money.perspective_relevance: As an expert in macroeconomics with a focus on the Quantity Theory of Money (QTM), I bring a framework that links inflation to changes in money supply, velocity, output, and structural credibility in monetary policy. Argentina's history of chronic inflation—often due to fiscal dominance and monetization of deficits—makes the QTM particularly salient. Analyzing recent shifts in monetary aggregates, fiscal stance, and public trust in the peso is crucial for forecasting inflation dynamics.
Macroeconomics (Quantity Theory of Money.status_quo: The status quo is chronic high inflation: from 211% in December 2023, peaking near 300% in early 2024, but now reported at 31.8–33.6% as of September 2025. The secular trend (pre-Milei) was persistent double- or triple-digit inflation, with repeated failed stabilization attempts.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Money Supply and Monetary Policy Stance
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability of high inflation; since mid-2024 the money supply has reportedly been fixed, with sharp fiscal tightening and central bank currency interventions. This aligns with the QTM: if M is stable and V does not spike, inflation should slow.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Credibility and Public Trust in the Peso
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Partially decreases probability; political and institutional credibility has improved under Milei, but remains fragile. Any major loss of confidence could quickly reverse recent gains, as Argentine savers have a short fuse for switching to dollars.

Decreases probability; aggressive spending cuts, removal of subsidies, and a shift from deficit to surplus have directly reduced pressure for central bank financing of deficits—a key source of past inflation.

Slightly increases probability; political risks are rising ahead of the October 26, 2025 midterm elections. If Milei’s coalition loses, reforms may stall or reverse, undermining anti-inflation credibility.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: External Support and Foreign Currency Inflows
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability; the $20B US-backed package and IMF support have stabilized reserves and allowed for limited FX interventions, buying time for reforms to take hold.
Decreases probability; the very high inflation base in late 2024 means YoY comparisons for December 2025 will likely be favorable if monthly inflation stays low through Q4 2025.
Decreases probability; monthly inflation has been under 2% since May 2025. A 1.5–2.1% MoM rate annualizes to 20–28%, supporting <30% YoY in December if trend holds.
Increases probability; the IMF recently revised 2025 inflation up to 28–41%—with some scenarios above 30%. Private forecasts tend to cluster just below but are wide-ranging.
Increases probability; utility and regulated price adjustments, labor unrest, or new shocks (devaluation, terms of trade) could trigger higher prices late in the year.

Macroeconomics (Quantity Theory of Money.no_scenario: A 'No' outcome (inflation >=30%) could occur if political instability after the October midterms leads to a reversal or stalling of reforms, triggering capital flight, renewed peso depreciation, and inflation pass-through. Alternatively, if external support is withdrawn (e.g., due to US or IMF policy change), reserves are depleted, forcing a further devaluation and import price spike. Also possible if regulated prices are adjusted upwards late in the year or if fiscal discipline slips.
Macroeconomics (Quantity Theory of Money.yes_scenario: A 'Yes' outcome (inflation <30%) occurs if the current trend of low monthly inflation (1.5–2.1%) persists through Q4, reforms stay on track, and external support continues. Public trust holds, the peso remains stable, and no major supply or political shocks occur. The high December 2024 base ensures the YoY print benefits from base effects, offsetting any modest monthly uptick.
Macroeconomics (Quantity Theory of Money.final_reasoning: Base rates for Argentina sustaining inflation below 30% are historically low, but the current macro environment is dramatically different: money supply growth is near zero, fiscal balances have swung to surplus, and international reserves are propped up by US and IMF support. Recent monthly inflation rates (1.5–2.1%) are consistent with an annualized rate below 30%. IMF and other forecasts are split—some see risk of a late-year spike, others project a YoY print just below 30%. The biggest risk is political: if post-election instability undermines reforms or triggers a run on the peso, the trend could reverse quickly. However, with only 2–3 months left and the December 2024 base being extremely high, it would take a substantial and immediate shock to push December 2025 YoY above 30%. The QTM lens, plus recent data and base effects, suggest a 'Yes' outcome is more likely than not, but not a lock given Argentina's history of volatility.

Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).time_to_resolution: About 2 months (question resolves with December 2025 INDEC inflation data, likely published mid-January 2026)
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).perspective_relevance: As a macroeconomist specializing in the Phillips Curve, I focus on the relationship between inflation, unemployment, and output gaps, and how expectations and policy credibility shape inflation outcomes. Argentina is a classic case of chronic inflation driven by both structural (expectations, credibility, fiscal dominance) and cyclical (output gap, labor market slack) factors. The Phillips Curve perspective is particularly relevant now, as Argentina has undergone a shock-therapy disinflation with deep austerity and monetary contraction, raising questions about the sustainability of low inflation and the risks of inflation persistence or sudden reversals.
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).status_quo: Over the last four months (June–September 2025), monthly inflation in Argentina has stabilized around 1.7–2.1%, with the year-over-year (YoY) inflation rate falling to 31.8% in September 2025. If monthly inflation remains at 2% through December 2025, the YoY rate will be approximately 26–28% (since high-inflation months from late 2024 will roll off the annual window). However, any reacceleration or policy reversal could push YoY inflation back above 30%.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Historically, Argentina almost never achieves single-digit or low double-digit inflation for more than brief periods. Even after successful stabilization programs, inflation often rebounds due to structural rigidities, entrenched expectations, and political shocks. The base rate of sustained YoY inflation below 30% in Argentina is extremely low over the last three decades.

Increases probability. The monthly inflation rate has dropped sharply, and the YoY figure has already reached 31.8% in September 2025. If the 2% monthly pace continues or improves, the math strongly favors a YoY figure under 30% by December 2025, as the high-inflation months from late 2024 drop out of the annual calculation.

Increases probability. The Milei administration has delivered a genuine fiscal surplus, slashed spending, and imposed tight monetary policy. Money supply growth has been sharply curtailed. These are textbook prerequisites for durable disinflation, and so far, they are working.

Decreases probability. With midterm elections in late October 2025, political stability is uncertain. If Milei’s coalition loses control or faces mass protests, there could be a reversal of reforms, fiscal slippage, or currency market panic, which would risk a sudden inflation spike that would affect the December 2025 print.

Increases probability, but with caveats. The US-backed $20B currency support and IMF loans have stabilized the peso short-term. As long as reserves hold and the peso does not devalue sharply in Q4, imported inflation will remain subdued. However, this support is contingent on policy continuity and market confidence, which could be fragile if political shocks happen.

Neutral to slightly decreases probability. There are accusations that INDEC’s figures understate actual inflation and poverty, although the YoY CPI series remains the standard for question resolution. If inflation is understated but the official print is below 30%, the question will still resolve Yes.

Increases probability. The deep recession and high unemployment (with rising to 7.5% per IMF) create slack, which in traditional Phillips Curve logic reduces wage and price pressures and supports low inflation, at least in the short run.

Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).no_scenario: A 'No' outcome (December 2025 YoY inflation at or above 30%) occurs if: (1) political instability after the October 2025 midterms leads to a loss of market confidence, (2) the peso devalues sharply (e.g., due to capital flight, loss of US/IMF support, or a run on FX reserves), (3) Milei's reforms are partially reversed or fiscal discipline falters, or (4) there is an exogenous shock (e.g., a surge in global energy/food prices or a major labor protest forcing wage hikes). In these cases, monthly inflation could reaccelerate above 2.5–3% late in the year, pushing the YoY figure back above 30%.
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).yes_scenario: A 'Yes' outcome (December 2025 YoY inflation below 30%) occurs if: (1) monthly inflation broadly maintains its current pace (1.7–2.2% per month through Q4), (2) Milei’s administration survives the midterms and maintains tight fiscal/monetary policy, (3) the peso remains stable or only depreciates moderately, and (4) external support (US, IMF) remains in place to backstop the currency and reserves. In this scenario, by December, the high-inflation months from late 2024 will have dropped out of the YoY calculation, and the math will almost certainly yield a figure in the 25–29% range.
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).final_reasoning: The question hinges on whether Argentina can avoid a late-2025 inflation shock. As of October 2025, the monthly inflation rate is running at or just above 2%, and the YoY rate is already at 31.8% and trending down. If nothing changes, simple arithmetic—with moderately low monthly inflation—almost guarantees a December YoY print below 30%. The base rate of Argentine stabilization failures is relevant, but current policy is unusually tight, and external support is robust, at least through the midterms. The main risk to a 'Yes' is political: a loss for Milei’s coalition or a major social backlash could unwind reforms, trigger a currency crisis, or lead to 'one-off' administrative price hikes. However, such a reversal would have to occur in the next 1–2 months and immediately reaccelerate monthly inflation to above 3–4% to push the YoY rate back over 30% by December. The Phillips Curve perspective suggests further downward pressure on prices via recession and labor market slack. On balance, the probability is very high—though not absolute, due to Argentina’s history of shocks and policy reversals—that the December 2025 YoY print will be below 30%. I assign a probability of 88%.

Macroeconomics (Expectation Augmented In.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.5 months until December 2025 INDEC inflation data is published (likely mid-January 2026).
Macroeconomics (Expectation Augmented In.perspective_relevance: As an expert in macroeconomics, specifically in expectation-augmented inflation, my perspective brings focus to the role of inflation expectations, credibility of policy, and the lagged effects of monetary and fiscal changes—key in Argentina's volatility-ridden context. My assessment is grounded in how expectations (public, investors, firms) and policy credibility shape price/wage setting, and how persistent inflation inertia can be even when headline rates fall. Argentina’s history of expectation-driven inflation makes this lens essential for understanding risks of re-acceleration or disinflation persistence.
Macroeconomics (Expectation Augmented In.status_quo: Argentina's YoY inflation rate for September 2025 is just above 30% (INDEC: 31.8%); monthly inflation is hovering near 2%. The current trend is downward, but the 12-month trailing inflation is still above the 30% threshold.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Reduces probability. While Milei’s government has delivered sharp disinflation, the durability of reforms and ability to anchor expectations are in question given looming elections, political instability, and historical reversals. The expectation-augmented model warns that without entrenched credibility, disinflation can stall or reverse quickly.

Increases probability. Monthly inflation has been at or below 2% for several consecutive months, and the YoY rate has fallen dramatically since 2024, suggesting substantial inertia in the disinflation process.

Increases probability. The massive spikes in late 2023 and early 2024 will drop out of the 12-month window by December 2025, mechanically lowering the YoY rate. If monthly inflation remains below 2% through December, sub-30% YoY inflation is mathematically plausible.

Reduces probability. The October 2025 midterms, rising Peronist opposition, and corruption allegations increase the risk of policy reversal, populist measures, or loss of market confidence, which could destabilize expectations and trigger renewed currency depreciation and inflation.

Increases probability. US-backed $20B swap and IMF support have bolstered reserves and provided a short-term 'blindaje' against currency crisis, supporting the peso and limiting pass-through to prices.

Reduces probability. Deep poverty, eroded public services, and rising unemployment could force the government to loosen fiscal discipline or reintroduce subsidies, risking inflation acceleration if markets lose faith.

Mixed effect. IMF forecasts have consistently overestimated inflation since 2024, but their October 2025 update still puts 2025 inflation at 28-41%. Market surveys are more optimistic, but the uncertainty band is wide.

Macroeconomics (Expectation Augmented In.no_scenario: Monthly inflation creeps above 2.5-3% in Q4 2025 due to currency pressure, political instability after the October election (e.g., Peronist resurgence or policy reversal), or a new external shock (commodity prices, global risk-off). As a result, the YoY rate bottoms out in the low 30s or higher, failing to break the 30% threshold. Alternatively, official statistics are revised or manipulated upward under political pressure.
Macroeconomics (Expectation Augmented In.yes_scenario: Monthly inflation remains at or below 2% for October-December 2025 (as has been the trend since mid-year), and the lags/mechanics of YoY calculation allow the December 2024-December 2025 window to capture mainly the period post-shock, dropping the high values from late 2024. No major currency crisis or policy reversal occurs, and official INDEC statistics report a final YoY CPI of 29.x% or below.
Macroeconomics (Expectation Augmented In.final_reasoning: The base rate for disinflation in Argentina is low—historically, rapid gains are often reversed. However, the current combination of monetary/fiscal austerity, external support, and recent inflation prints (monthly rates at 1.5-2.1% since May) provide a plausible path to sub-30% YoY inflation by December 2025, given base effects alone. Most official (INDEC) and some market projections are now in the 28-35% band. While the IMF's higher figure (41.3%) may reflect caution and the risk of reversal, they have been consistently too pessimistic since 2024. The main threat is a political shock post-midterms that causes a sharp loss of confidence, fiscal slippage, or depreciation, but with only 2.5 months left and external backing, the probability of such a severe short-term reversal before December is under 50%, though not negligible. Given the expectation-augmented model, if inflation expectations remain anchored for even a few more months, the mechanical drop is likely. The risk of data manipulation is present but not prominent given current scrutiny. I assign a 68% probability to YoY inflation coming in below 30% for December 2025—significantly above 50%, but not extreme, reflecting both the positive trend and persistent downside tail risk tied to Argentina's history and current political turbulence.

Political Economy (Public Choice Theory).time_to_resolution: About 2.5 months (resolves with December 2025 inflation data, likely reported in January 2026)
Political Economy (Public Choice Theory).perspective_relevance: As an expert in Political Economy and Public Choice Theory, I focus on the political incentives, institutional constraints, time inconsistency problems, and credibility issues that shape macroeconomic outcomes in states with a history of populism and weak institutions. In Argentina, the interplay between reform ambitions, entrenched interests, and public expectations is critical for inflation dynamics. This perspective allows for a nuanced assessment of whether current stabilization gains can persist in the face of political shocks and reversion risks.
Political Economy (Public Choice Theory).status_quo: The status quo is that Argentina's annual inflation rate remains high relative to global standards but has fallen dramatically from nearly 300% in early 2024 to 31.8% as of September 2025. Recent monthly inflation rates have stabilized around 2%, and official projections (from both the IMF and government) for December 2025 vary between 28% and 41%. The policy regime is one of aggressive fiscal and monetary tightening under President Milei, but with rising political and social pushback.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Credibility and Durability of Austerity and Reform
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Milei’s government has so far maintained a strict fiscal and monetary stance, with deep spending cuts and reduced monetary expansion. This has rapidly curbed high-frequency inflation. The absence of large-scale policy reversals and the ability to secure external financing (IMF, US swaps) support the sustainability of low inflation at least through the forecast window.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Political Risk and Public Choice Dynamics
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Argentina has a long history of policy reversals—especially near elections—due to political incentives to relax austerity or spend more to placate voters or coalition partners. The October 2025 midterms and recent Peronist electoral wins increase the risk of backsliding, weakening anti-inflation credibility.

Decreases probability. While Argentina has recently achieved rapid disinflation, historically, such episodes are fragile. Structural inflation in Argentina has averaged ~189% (1944–2025), and almost all previous stabilization attempts failed to bring YoY inflation sustainably below 30% for more than a few months, usually due to political or social backlash or external shocks.

Increases probability. The US/IMF support packages and the willingness of external actors to intervene (e.g., the $20B swap, direct dollar purchases) appear to have strengthened the peso and provide a temporary anchor, reducing the risk of near-term currency collapse that would reignite inflation.

Decreases probability. There are credible allegations (from INDEC staff, independent economists, and international observers) that official inflation and poverty data may be underestimating actual figures, especially in sensitive sectors like food, services, and utilities. If official data is manipulated, the 'true' YoY inflation may exceed 30% even if the reported figure does not.

Decreases probability. The social costs of adjustment are accumulating: poverty, unemployment, and wage losses are rising, and local elections show declining support for Milei’s coalition. This raises the risk of partial policy reversal (e.g., reintroducing subsidies, relaxing wage controls) before year-end, especially if political pressures mount after the midterms.

Increases probability. Monthly inflation rates have been at or below 2% for several consecutive months, which mechanically points to a YoY number just below or at 30% for December 2025 if this trend continues and there is no sharp peso devaluation.

Political Economy (Public Choice Theory).no_scenario: After the October 2025 midterms, Milei’s government faces growing unrest and a weakening political coalition. To quell protests or secure legislative support, it partially reverses austerity—raising spending, relaxing wage/pension freezes, or reintroducing subsidies. The peso depreciates, and monthly inflation ticks up in November or December 2025, driving the YoY figure above 30%. Alternatively, even if the policy stance holds, food, utility, or service inflation outpaces official indices, and/or data manipulation underreports inflation, but international monitors (IMF, independent economists) reveal the true figure is above 30%, leading Metaculus to resolve 'No'.
Political Economy (Public Choice Theory).yes_scenario: Milei’s government survives the midterms without major policy reversal, continues strict fiscal and monetary discipline, and receives ongoing external support. Monthly inflation remains at or below 2% through December. Even if social costs are high, the government maintains credibility and resists populist incentives to loosen policy. Official INDEC data reports YoY inflation for December 2025 at 28–29%, and international monitors concur, leading to a 'Yes' resolution.
Political Economy (Public Choice Theory).final_reasoning: The probability of Argentina achieving sub-30% YoY inflation for December 2025 is higher than at any point in recent history, due to the unprecedented fiscal/monetary tightening, international support, and recent monthly inflation performance. However, Argentina’s historical base rate of failed stabilization, the looming risk of policy reversal around/after the October midterms, and evidence of both social and political strain significantly temper confidence. Additionally, concerns about data credibility add downside risk. Public Choice theory highlights that governments facing declining support and rising unrest are strongly tempted to backtrack on painful reforms—especially in the months immediately following elections, when the threat of future accountability is low but coalition maintenance is crucial. On the other hand, the combination of external anchors, still-high real interest rates, and the political cost to Milei of losing his anti-inflation credentials may help discipline behavior through year-end. The recent monthly inflation figures (~2%) are consistent with a December YoY number just below 30%, but only if there are no late-year shocks or policy slippage. Given these countervailing forces—and weighting the base rate of failure more heavily due to Argentina’s structural vulnerabilities—I assign a probability slightly below even odds, but higher than most historical periods would justify.

Political Economy (Institutionalism).time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.5 months (until the release of December 2025 inflation data, likely mid-January 2026).
Political Economy (Institutionalism).perspective_relevance: As an expert in Political Economy (Institutionalism), I focus on how institutional structures, credibility, policy stickiness, and political constraints shape macroeconomic outcomes. Argentina’s inflation history is tightly bound to its institutional weaknesses: fiscal dominance, weak central bank independence, lack of monetary credibility, and the social contract underpinning state-market relations. These factors provide a framework for evaluating whether recent stabilization is durable and if institutional reforms can anchor low inflation.
Political Economy (Institutionalism).status_quo: The most recent official data (September 2025) shows annual inflation at 31.8%, with monthly rates hovering around 2%. The IMF’s October 2025 projections for 2025 year-end annual inflation range from 28% (WEO) to 41% (country report), while the government and some private forecasts are in the 26-28% range. If nothing changes, the annual inflation rate by December 2025 will remain just above or just below 30%.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Milei’s government has achieved an impressive fiscal adjustment, large subsidy cuts, and monetary restraint, with rapid inflation deceleration. However, Argentina’s institutions are historically fragile: central bank independence is limited, and prior reforms have proven hard to sustain. A credible commitment to low inflation is necessary, but public and market expectations remain fragile and can shift quickly. This factor slightly increases the probability inflation stays low, but the risk of backsliding is non-negligible.

Milei’s coalition faces critical midterm legislative elections in October 2025. Recent Peronist victories in local elections and reports of scandals suggest Milei’s political support is fragile. If the opposition gains control or blocks legislation, or if unrest escalates due to austerity, policy reversal or slippage becomes more likely. This creates downside risk to continued stabilization, modestly increasing the chance of inflation bouncing above 30%.

U.S. and IMF support (via swaps and loans) has stabilized reserves and the peso, enabling the current regime. However, these are short-term fixes; external vulnerability persists. If reserves run low, or if the U.S. or IMF withdraw support (e.g., if Milei loses political legitimacy), pressure on the peso could return, risking a renewed inflationary surge. For now, the support appears intact through year-end, but the risk is not zero. This slightly increases the risk of a 'No' outcome.

Historically, Argentina has rarely sustained annual inflation below 30% without deep, credible reforms (e.g., Convertibility era 1991-2001). However, monthly inflation has been below 2-2.5% for several months, suggesting that the 12-month rolling rate will continue to fall sharply, barring a shock. The base rate for a rapid, lasting collapse in inflation is low, but the trend is favorable. This factor increases the probability of a 'Yes' outcome.

Some news sources and analysts allege that INDEC statistics understate true inflation and poverty, or that methodology changes have been made for political purposes. If this becomes more widely accepted or if data integrity is challenged, even if official numbers show <30%, the resolution may be contested. For the purposes of this question, resolution is by official INDEC data, but this is a minor caveat.

Political Economy (Institutionalism).no_scenario: After the midterm elections, Milei’s coalition loses political support or faces heightened unrest. Fiscal slippage and/or softening of reforms occur under political pressure, markets lose confidence, the peso depreciates, and inflation expectations rise. External financing is delayed, or reserves dwindle, forcing the central bank to ease monetary conditions. Monthly inflation rises above 2.5-3% in late 2025, keeping year-over-year inflation stuck above 30% (e.g., 31-35%).
Political Economy (Institutionalism).yes_scenario: Milei’s government maintains fiscal surpluses and monetary restraint through year-end, with external support from the U.S./IMF bolstering the peso. Monthly inflation stays at or below 2% through December. Base effects from the 2024 inflation spike roll out of the 12-month window, and the official annual rate for December 2025 drops below 30% (e.g., 26-29%). Even if the political situation is tense, the government avoids policy reversals and the official INDEC data show a 'Yes' outcome.
Political Economy (Institutionalism).final_reasoning: The official year-over-year inflation is falling rapidly and is on the cusp of the 30% threshold, with September’s rate at 31.8% and monthly inflation around/below 2%. If this pace continues, the December 2025 YoY CPI will almost certainly be below 30%. However, the risk of political instability, potential for policy slippage after the October elections, and Argentina’s institutional fragility cannot be ignored. Nevertheless, there is no evidence (yet) of a sharp policy reversal, and external financing has bought time. Most international and government projections now cluster in the 26-29% range; only the more pessimistic IMF scenario has inflation above 30%. The status quo, trend, and base rates (given the sharp drop in monthly inflation) all point to a high probability of 'Yes', but not certainty, given Argentina’s volatile history and the political calendar. I estimate the probability at 82%, reflecting both the strong recent trend and the persistent risk of reversal before year-end.

Latin American Studies (Dependency Theor.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.5 months (question resolves with December 2025 YoY inflation, official data likely available by mid-January 2026).
Latin American Studies (Dependency Theor.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Latin American Studies with a focus on Dependency Theory, I bring a critical, structural perspective that emphasizes the historically entrenched cycles of external dependency, fiscal vulnerability, and political volatility that shape Argentina’s macroeconomic outcomes. This lens helps uncover the deeper constraints (e.g., reliance on foreign capital, IMF conditionality, and vulnerability to capital flight) that often undermine short-term technocratic fixes, even amid apparent statistical improvements.
Latin American Studies (Dependency Theor.status_quo: As of October 2025, Argentina's YoY inflation rate is reported at roughly 31.8% (September 2025), down dramatically from 211% a year prior. The IMF, World Bank, and official Argentine government projections for December 2025 range from 28% (optimistic) to 41% (pessimistic). The most recent monthly inflation readings are slightly above 2%. Political and social tensions are rising around the midterm elections, and there are doubts regarding both the sustainability and the statistical accuracy of official inflation and poverty figures.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Historical Structural Inflation and Dollarization Trap
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Argentina's chronic inflation is rooted in deep distrust in the peso, preference for dollars, and frequent external shocks. Structural reforms have repeatedly failed, and the country’s history suggests rapid disinflation is rarely sustained.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Short-Term Policy Successes and IMF/US Backing
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Milei's aggressive fiscal adjustment, devaluation, and foreign support have rapidly reduced inflation, providing an external buffer (e.g., $20B US/IMF package) and a sharp drop in money supply growth.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Political Instability and Risk of Policy Reversal
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Political risk is acute: if Milei’s coalition loses the midterms or faces further legitimacy crises, market and policy instability could trigger a reversal, capital flight, or a return to populist inflationary policies.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Credibility and Manipulation of Official Statistics
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Serious doubts surround the accuracy of INDEC’s official statistics, with independent analysts and opposition NGOs citing underreporting of poverty and inflation. If inflation is understated, the true figure may exceed the threshold.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate and Global Economic Conditions
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Historically, Argentina has sustained sub-30% inflation for only brief periods, and global risks (commodity prices, US monetary policy, Chinese demand) could quickly impact the fragile external balance.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent Inflation Trajectory and Market Expectations
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. The monthly inflation rate has stabilized below 2.5% for several consecutive months, and the trend is clearly downward, which, if sustained, would yield a December 2025 YoY figure just below 30%.

Latin American Studies (Dependency Theor.no_scenario: A resurgence of political instability after the October 2025 midterms undermines Milei’s coalition. This triggers capital flight, peso depreciation, and a spike in monthly inflation. The government is pressured into easing fiscal adjustment (reintroducing subsidies or public sector spending) or faces social unrest that forces monetary expansion. The official INDEC figure for December 2025 YoY inflation comes in at 31% or higher, driven by a renewed inflationary pulse in Q4.
Latin American Studies (Dependency Theor.yes_scenario: Despite political tensions, Milei’s administration maintains fiscal and monetary discipline, continues to receive foreign support (from IMF/US), and keeps monthly inflation below 2% through Q4 2025. Even with some upward pressure, the base effect from the high-inflation end of 2024 means the December 2025 YoY figure dips just below 30% (e.g., 28–29%), and INDEC reports it as such.
Latin American Studies (Dependency Theor.final_reasoning: The probability hinges on whether Milei’s stabilization program can maintain discipline and avoid political or external shocks through year-end. The downward trend in monthly inflation is real, and the YoY figure is poised to slip below 30% if this trend persists. However, Argentina’s chronic structural vulnerabilities—dependency on external capital, the legacy of inflationary inertia, and high political risk—mean that even brief instability or a policy setback could push the annual figure above 30%. Doubts about the reliability of INDEC data add a layer of uncertainty, but for Metaculus resolution, the official number is decisive. The base rate for Argentina sustaining sub-30% inflation is low, but current trends are unprecedentedly sharp. Weighing these factors, I judge a sub-30% YoY figure for December 2025 as slightly more likely than not, but with significant risk of reversal.

Latin American Studies (Populism in Lati.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.5 months (until INDEC releases December 2025 YoY inflation in January 2026)
Latin American Studies (Populism in Lati.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Latin American Studies with a focus on populism, I bring an understanding of Argentina's deep-rooted political-economic cycles, the legacy of populist (mainly Peronist) policy reversals, and the structural reasons for chronic inflation. I can contextualize recent macroeconomic improvements against decades of volatility, skepticism toward official data, sociopolitical backlash, and the risks of policy reversal after elections—factors frequently overlooked in purely econometric models.
Latin American Studies (Populism in Lati.status_quo: The YoY inflation rate for September 2025 is 31.8%, with a slight monthly uptick to 2.1%. Monthly inflation has been below 2% for most of the past four months, and the trajectory since early 2024 has been sharply downward, but remains just above the 30% threshold.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Chronic distrust in the peso and a strong preference for dollar assets mean that any political or market instability can quickly reverse disinflationary momentum, as shown historically and in recent months (e.g., the market reaction to Peronist electoral gains).

Decreases probability. The approaching October 26 midterm election poses a risk: if Milei’s coalition loses ground, market actors may anticipate (or accelerate) a reversal of reforms, causing a spike in expectations and real inflation. Latin American populist cycles often see rapid policy reversals after electoral setbacks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent Macroeconomic Improvements and External Support
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Milei’s deep fiscal cuts, tight monetary stance, and US/IMF support have achieved a dramatic reduction in inflation, with monthly rates now at or below 2%. External financing and currency swaps have stabilized reserves and the exchange rate, at least temporarily.

Decreases probability. There is widespread skepticism about official INDEC statistics, with independent observers and social organizations claiming underreporting of poverty and inflation. If the government’s credibility is further undermined, expectations may become unanchored, and official versus real inflation may diverge.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate of Sustained Disinflation in Argentina
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Historically, Argentina has rarely achieved and sustained YoY inflation below 30% after periods of hyperinflation—most stabilization attempts (e.g., Cavallo’s convertibility) unraveled within a few years due to political, social, or external shocks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: International Commodity Prices and External Shocks
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral to slightly negative. Argentina's external position remains vulnerable to commodity price swings and global financial conditions. A sudden drop in agricultural export prices or tightening of global credit could destabilize the fragile equilibrium.

Latin American Studies (Populism in Lati.no_scenario: After the October 26 legislative elections, Milei's coalition loses significant ground. Markets anticipate a return of Peronist policies or a stalling of reforms, triggering capital flight, peso depreciation, and a spike in inflation expectations. The government, lacking political capital and external support, is forced to loosen monetary policy or intervene in ways that reignite inflation. By December 2025, YoY inflation is above 30% (e.g., in the 32–38% range), possibly with monthly readings creeping up to 2.5–3% as uncertainty mounts.
Latin American Studies (Populism in Lati.yes_scenario: Milei’s coalition holds enough ground in the midterms to avoid a market panic. The government maintains tight fiscal and monetary policy, and external support from the US and IMF continues. Monthly inflation stays at or below 2% for the remainder of 2025. Even with some volatility, base effects from high 2024 inflation push the December 2025 YoY figure below 30% (e.g., 28–29.5%), and INDEC reports this official number. Markets remain cautiously optimistic, and no major social or political upheaval occurs in Q4 2025.
Latin American Studies (Populism in Lati.final_reasoning: The latest official INDEC data shows September 2025 YoY inflation at 31.8%, and monthly rates have stabilized at or just below 2%. Optimistic projections (including some from the IMF, with caveats) suggest a 28–41% range for 2025; official government projections are more bullish. However, the trend is positive and, barring a major shock, further disinflation is likely, especially due to base effects from the extremely high 2024 inflation. That said, Argentina’s history argues for caution—political risk around the October midterms is high, and market/expectational volatility has already been seen after Peronist victories. There is also a non-negligible risk that post-election instability or loss of confidence will nudge inflation back above 30%, though the government and external backers appear committed to maintaining the stabilization effort. The probability is therefore close to the threshold, with a slight lean toward a 'No' (i.e., YoY inflation remaining just above 30%) due to structural, political, and credibility constraints. However, the downward trend and base effects mean the 'Yes' scenario is plausible, especially if Milei avoids major setbacks. My forecast: 40%.
